comments: Small class held over zoom, with frequent engagement from each student.
No other modes.
We also gave several individual in-class presentations (remotely), had short lectures to elaborate on content, and reviewed chapter exercises in Zoom breakout rooms.
Optional asynchronous assignments.

On synchronous days (MWF) we received instruction from the Professor and then often separated into breakout rooms to do group work and review/practice concepts from previously assigned homework. On asynchronous days, our work was facilitated by the pre-recorded lectures/modules on the website meant to accompany our textbook.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained several important skills within the language, particularly writing and speaking. I improved the accuracy and clarity of my Spanish greatly.
I developed a stronger work ethic because I had to complete assignments every day. I gained the skill of speaking Spanish more fluently than before.
I feel like I gained a good understanding of Spanish at the L2 level.
I grew very greatly in my ability to write, understand, and use Spanish, but especially in my ability to speak it.

Spanish 120 goes over an enormous amount of vocab and language skills. This is where you learn the "bulk" of Spanish. From what I understand, 110 will get you the basics, and this is where it gets real. After taking 120, you should be able to understand just about any Spanish, given that you learn the specific vocab and you learn more colloquial/slang Spanish.

We learned how to talk about health, technology, driving, housing, nature, running errands in a city, exercise, dieting, and applying to jobs. A lot of our work focused on conjugating in the past tense (reviewing imperfect and preterite), present subjunctive, future tense, incorporating past participles, as well as informal and formal commands.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course include some of the projects in class, the textbook/Supersite combination, and the repetitiveness of the learning to solidify skills. There are many weaknesses, including unclear expectations, a grueling work load, constant homework and testing (at least one big examination per week) and the general stress that this course induces.
Strengths: Consistency created a successful class. Weaknesses: Because the class required so much work without variation I felt very burnt out and frustrated with the class towards the end.

This course has a lot of support from the Spanish dept. and team of L2 instructors, and it is very well designed. I think in the online format this year perhaps the ratio of presentations to other kinds of speaking practice was a bit high, but ultimately the workload was distributed well.

It is VERY time consuming. However, I want to learn a language. The time commitment is both a strength and a weakness. I think letting students know what they are in for before reading period would be useful.
Very engaging and very kind professor who taught very well.

While I understand all language programs at Yale are meant to be intense, I felt like given the circumstances, the work was less conducive to learning than originally intended. For example, there were way more presentations than I expected when I entered the class. I do feel like my oral skills got better, but having to prepare a four-minute-long presentation from memory week after week for over a month encouraged memorization over actual comprehension and speaking skills. I felt like I spent a lot of time trying to regurgitate words rather than use grammatical structures and vocabulary more organically. The back-to-back cultural presentations left little room to work with the vocab from units we were actually studying, and in writing our scripts, we often had to teach ourselves new vocabulary which wasn't as accessible to our peers when we presented. In reading and writing assignments, I wish we could have spent more time with the new grammatical structures, which would better prepare us for quizzes and exams.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: COVID presented very few actual challenges for the learning of Spanish, other than the occasional Zoom problems which rarely caused real learning deficits. Generally the worst side effect of the pandemic on this course was the increased workload it induced. In an effort to "catch up" or "account for" the "virtual shortfalls" of the pandemic, the teachers would assign completely excessive workloads and examinations in order to, quote, "keep us moving" because they were so afraid that we would not learn in the virtual setting. In reality, this increase of workload only increased anxiety, and we spent more of our "limited" time in class doing examination than anything else. Overall this course didn't have problems with the virtual learning, only the instructors responses to the anticipated problems.

Succeeded: breakout rooms to get to know classmates better. Good online format for homework. 
Could be improved: The test format has black and white answers that would sometimes mark correct answers incorrect. Virtual class was more difficult all around.

Class discussions were fairly successful, and the oral presentations (especially the mock trial and Cervantes projects) gave us a lot of speaking practice. Also, small-group breakout rooms were helpful for reviewing textbook activities and practicing speaking.
Zoom worked. In the least, our professor made it work. However, breakout rooms in Spanish class just don't seem like they can serve students after about 5 minutes of activity.
syllabus could be better tailored to the online environment.

Everything was taught remotely, so in regards to safety and accessibility, this course was successful. I appreciate that language tables were still offered, but I didn't get a chance to attend them because of schedule conflicts. I think the department really tried to maintain strong engagement, and the film series encouraged student participation with the incentive of extra credit. But languages are best learned when students can practice with one another, and despite the good opportunities, it still felt hard to reach out and make the connection to resources that would improve my learning experience.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely not recommend this course to any other student, in fact I looked into dropping it. If you are like me and need this to fulfill the language requirement, weigh all of your options carefully... This course was my least favorite class of the entire semester for a variety of reasons. First, don't be fooled by the title "Elementary Spanish", you will be expected to perform miracles in this short semester; by the end we were giving weekly presentations memorized, taking tests every other week, and during all of this you will be doing excessive homework every day for content that you may or may not be graded on or cover in class. Additionally, with only one semester of prerequisite knowledge, you will be expected to have a natural accent and conversational fluency in order to get good grades; no matter how hard I tried, it was never enough for my professor. Overall the workload for this course is completely ridiculous, and if you need the credit and have to take it, buena suerte...
I would recommend this to another student seeking to learn more Spanish.

This class was a positive introductory Spanish experience in my opinion. Its definitely manageable if you stay on top of the homework assignments, do the Supersite practice, and (assuming the presentation schedule stays the same) complete those early to give you time to practice them.
If they want to truly learn Spanish and quickly, yes I would.
